Graphical abstract This review summarize the surface engineering of HEMs for improving electrocatalytic performance and the catalytic mechanisms related to their structural features. High entropy materials (HEMs) are the promising electrocatalysts for anion exchange membrane electrolyser (AEMs) and proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) due to the intriguing cocktail effect, wide design space, tailorable electronic structure, and entropy stabilization effect. The precise fabrication of HEMs with functional nanostructures provides a crucial avenue to optimize the adsorption strength and catalytic activity for electrocatalysis. This review comprehensively summarizes the development of HEMs, focusing on the principles and strategies of structural design, and the catalytic mechanism towards hydrogen evolution reaction, oxygen evolution reaction and oxygen reduction reaction for the development of high-performance electrocatalysts. The complexity inherent in the interactions between different elements, the changes in the d-band center and the Gibbs free energies during the catalytic progress, as well as the coordination environment of the active sites associated with the unique crystal structure to improve the catalytic performance are discussed. We also provide a perspective on the challenges and future development direction of HEMs in electrocatalysis. This review will contribute to the design and development of HEMs-based catalysts for the next generation of electrochemical applications. Keywords High entropy materials Structural design Electrocatalytic performance Functional mechanism 1 Introduction Amid the escalating energy crisis and environmental challenges driven by the rapid depletion of fossil fuels, there is an urgent demand for advanced clean energy solutions. Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel cells (PEMFCs) are promising electrochemical devices for mitigating climate change and environmental challenges and enhancing energy security [1–3]. These PEMFCs can directly convert energy from hydrogen and oxygen into electricity in a zero-emission process. The recombination of H2 and O2 produced by electrocatalytic overall water splitting provides a promising zero-emission energy source for practical clean energy applications [4,5]. To enable scalable hydrogen-based energy systems, the development of efficient electrocatalysts is critical for three key reactions: the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in anion exchange membrane (AEM) electrolyzers [6–8], and the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in PEMFCs PEMFCs [9–11]. However, AEMs and PEMFCs currently are far from commercialization and face some challenges, such as the high cost of high-content noble metals (e.g., Pt, Ir and RuO2), the sluggish catalytic kinetics and the poor durability of electrocatalysts under harsh conditions [12,13]. In response to these challenges, there is an urgent need to develop readily available and cost-effective alternative electrocatalysts that exhibit comparable or even superior catalytic performance to noble metal-based catalysts under harsh conditions. High entropy materials (HEMs) have emerged as promising candidates in the field of electrocatalysis due to their variable compositions and exceptional functional properties [14–17], which offer a competitive superiority in electrocatalytic applications by breaking the proportional limitation that traditionally restricts the electrocatalytic activity of transition metal catalysts (Scheme 1 ) [18,19]. The typical definition of HEMs is described as materials containing five or more elements in nearly equal atomic ratios, with each element content ranging from 5 ​% to 35 % (at.%) [20]. They benefit from the unique high-entropy effect, lattice distortion, slow diffusion, and the cocktail effect [21,22], thereby exhibiting superior activity and stability to HER, OER, and ORR [23,24]. Since the first report of high-entropy alloys (HEAs) in 2004, a substantial family of HEMs has been developed. HEMs do not have a universally agreed-upon definition [25]. However, there are specific criteria that help to identify a material as an HEM. Tracing their origins back to metallurgy, HEMs have eventually evolved into subclasses such as high entropy alloys, oxides, carbides, nitrides, and others, including HEAs [26–30], high-entropy oxides (HEOs) [31–34], high-entropy sulfides (HESs) [35–38], and high-entropy layered double hydroxides (HELDHs) [39–41]. These have been developed for efficient electrocatalysis (Scheme 2 ). HEMs catalysts provide hard-won opportunities in the realm of electrocatalysis, while their complex coordination environment and local electronic structure also pose major challenges in the elucidation of electrocatalytic mechanisms. The coordination environment in HEMs exhibits significant dynamic complexity, arising from short-range lattice distortions caused by the incorporation of multiple metal sites, each possessing distinct atomic radii and unique coordination geometries. As a result, the electronic structure of the electrocatalyst surface is affected, thus tailoring the surface adsorption energy of the intermediates formed during catalysis. Consequently, the adsorption–desorption processes, which are governed by the electron transfer behavior of the intermediates, become more complicated to predict. To elucidate the catalytic mechanism of HEMs, considerable efforts have been made to fabricate HEMs with functional nanostructures. Numerous studies have reviewed the development of HEMs in electrocatalytic applications. Recent advances in characterization techniques and machine learning have provided new insights into element selection, structural design, catalytic mechanisms, and dynamic structural evolution in HEMs during catalysis. This review provides a comprehensive overview of the research breakthroughs on the structural features of HEMs for HER, OER and ORR catalysis in the last three years. The present review focuses on the mechanism of the electronic structure on electrocatalytic performance, guided by the structural characteristics of HEMs. This includes the electron transfer, redistribution and recombination of electronic structures, the d-band resulting from the elemental composition and coordination environment, as well as catalytic performance driven by structural features. The paper goes on to describe the key theoretical aspects for the design concept and synthetic strategies of state-of-the-art HEMs based on thermodynamic and kinetic facets with tailored surface adsorption to improve catalytic performance. Crucial challenges, mitigation strategies and future research directions of HEMs in the field of electrocatalysis are also proposed. 2 Structural design of HEMs 2.1 Strain engineering Lattice strain has been widely observed in HEMs and plays an important role in electrocatalysis by influencing the binding effect between the catalyst surface and adsorbates [46–48]. Numerous studies have shown that lattice strain can induce the redistribution of surface electrons, which in turn leads to the altered d-band center, thereby regulating the binding energy of the reaction intermediates [49,50]. For example, Huang et al. [42] introduced soft metal ions into HESs to reduce the strain energy (Fig. 1 a). Due to the different M−S bond lengths, the prepared NiCoCuTiVS x exhibited low local strain with high catalytic performance. Essentially, lattice strain is associated with the expansion or contraction of the local crystal cell volume. The lattice mismatch resulting from the difference in atomic sizes imposes a high threshold for the precise control of lattice strain intensity, making it difficult to comprehensively illustrate the relationship between strain and catalytic activity. To overcome this challenge, Sun et al. [43] fabricated a Pt-based HEAs library containing 3–10 components via a reduction-diffusion strategy. The characterizations of these components showed that the mismatched lattice can affect the overlapping of the Pt d-orbitals, resulting in the shortened Pt-Pt bond (Fig. 1b and c). In a related study, Chen et al. [44] used anionic atoms to induce the formation of tensile strain in HEAs (Fig. 1d). Two coexisting phases with individual lattice expansion capabilities at the phase interface resulted in increased internal stress, thereby leading to strain amplification (Fig. 1e). The experimental results showed a direct correlation between the tensile strain and the P dopant content, with a maximum of 1.13% observed. Notably, the prepared electrocatalysts exhibited both high HER (η 10 = 70 mV) and OER (η 10 = 211 mV) activities, enabling their application for overall water splitting. Given the prevalence of coincident strain effects and ligand effects, it is challenging to precisely control over strain intensity and subsequent elucidation of the strain-activity relationship. Fabricating the FeCoNiCrPt HEA film by pulsed laser deposition and electrochemical etching, Yang et al. [45] found that the displacement of lattice sites was caused by the formation of vacancies, leading to the inhomogeneous lattice strain fluctuation (Fig. 1f). The strain distribution was related to both the location of vacancies and the arrangement of atoms. In particular, the tensile strain surrounds Pt atoms, whereas the compressive strain is accompanied by vacancies (Fig. 1g). Surfactants can significantly reduce the surface or interfacial tension between two substances. Due to their micellization properties, surfactants have been widely used in the structural design of nanomaterials. In a pioneering study, Wei et al. [51] used the surfactant triethyl benzyl ammonium chloride to control the design of stretchable Pt(Co/Ni)MoPdRh HEA nanoflowers. The as-prepared sample exhibits a flower-like nanostructure assembled by ultrathin nanosheets with a thickness of 1.68 nm (Fig. 2 a). The unique structure of the PtCoMoPdRh nanosheets exhibited the compressive strain of 9.6% and the tensile strain of 8.3%. The calculated free energy diagrams reveal that the strain can reduce the hydrogen adsorption free energy (ΔG H*) (Fig. 2b and c) and facilitate the Tafel step for HER. In a similar study, Cui et al. [52] prepared the PtCoNiRuIr HEA with a diameter of approximately 3.24 nm by a high-temperature liquid shock method using oleylamine and oleic acid as surfactants (Fig. 2d). The lattice strain was unevenly distributed and mainly located at the position of lattice distortions due to the different atomic radii of metallic atoms. In particular, the PtCoNiRuIr HEA catalyst exhibited enhanced mass activity and prolonged stability in the HER reaction. He et al. [53] used isolated Mo atoms to induce tensile strain in HEA nanosheets with the aid of a surfactant. The optimized Mo1-PdPtNiCuZn nanosheets exhibited an intrinsic tensile strain of 4.4%, a consequence of the disparity in atomic radii of metal components, concave defects, and the extremely small thickness. The tensile strain can elongate the Pt-Pt bond, tuning the d-d orbital interaction between the Pt-M coordination. Therefore, it couldlower the energy barrier of electron transfer and stabilize the valence state of Pt sites. Xu et al. [54] used ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid to induce tensile strain in the high entropy perovskite oxide of LaSr(5TM)O3 (TM = Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, and Ni). The tensile strain in the generated LaSr(5TM)O3 led to the additional electron transfer from Co and Cr to neighboring Fe and Ni sites at the B sites in the perovskite material, which modulated the binding energy between active sites and O-containing intermediates, thereby boosting the OER activity. It should be noted that excessive metal atoms in B-type metal sites of perovskites could cause severe structural distortion associated with high internal strain, leading to the collapse of the crystal structure. From the research results outlined above, it can be concluded that heteroatom doping and defects tend to induce the formation of lattice strain in HEMs. The strain magnitude may be significantly enhanced by synergistic effects of intensified crystalline mismatch and surfactant-assisted modulation. However, it should be noted that the intensity of the lattice strain is finite. Therefore, if the induced strain exceeds critical thresholds, it destabilizes the structural framework of materials, diminishing catalytic performance and stability in HEM-based systems. In addition, the changes in the coordination environments of active sites induced by the aforementioned tensile and compressive strains occur simultaneously. In general, tensile strain surrounds the metal atoms and results in stretched M−M bonds, while compressive strain is accompanied by vacancies and results in shortened M−M bonds. The coexistence of the two types of strains could reduce the reaction energy barrier during catalysis, thereby favoring surface electronic structures and thus facilitating catalytic kinetics. 2.2 Defect engineering Defects are a universal feature of solid materials and have a significant influence on the regulation of surface electrons and the design of geometric structures [59]. Considerable research efforts have been devoted to understanding and exploiting these defects for catalytic enhancement. In the context of fuel cells, the primary source of protons comes from the hydration of oxygen vacancies and external water molecules on the electrode, thereby affecting the performance of reversible proton ceramic cells [60,61]. To address this challenge, Sun et al. [62] fabricated a defective single BaCo0.2Fe0.2Zr0.2Sn0.2Pr0.2O3-δ in which the proton concentration in BCFZSP at 10% atm p(H2O) is 6.92 mol%, indicating the strong water adsorption capacity. As expected, the maximum power density of the fabricated full cell was 0.93 W cm−2 at 700 °C. In addition, Kuang et al. [55] discovered that the incorporation of defects into HELDHs can enhance the binding of *OH on active sites, thereby facilitating the release of oxygen from the lattice and consequently triggering the coupled oxygen evolution of OER (Fig. 3 a-c). Consequently, the prepared catalyst exhibited high OER activity, which remained stable and unresponsive to degradation when operated at over 100 mA cm−2 for 100 h. The incorporation of defects into HEMs can serve as an important strategy to enhance their catalytic activity. However, the construction of HEMs with a high degree of defects remains challenging. To address this challenge, Liao et al. [63] used a soft template and thermal treatment to prepare a unique non-equimolar metal HEO of (Fe0.27Ni0.35Co0.24Cr0.10Mn0.04)2O3-δ, with an oxygen vacancy content of 35.3%. The as-prepared catalyst exhibited both high OER and HER activity with low overpotentials of 174 and 60 mV at 10 mA cm−2, respectively. Furthermore, the assembled water splitting cell exhibited a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at 1.55 V. Additionally, He et al. [56] utilized thermal reduction technology to fabricate a defective CrMnFeCoNi HEA for ORR and OER as the cathode for zinc-air batteries. The as-prepared CrMnFeCoNi HEA in the twin structure had a high defect density due to the severe lattice distortion and dislocation (Fig. 3d). The DFT calculations showed that with the downshifted d-band centers, this catalyst exhibits weaker surface interaction for intermediates, which resulted in lower energy barrier for OER and ORR, leading to enhanced catalytic activity (Fig. 3e and f). Li et al. [64] anchored FeCoNiCuMn high entropy metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) on MXene to promote the charge transfer rate associated with the large orbital hybridization of elements at the Fermi level. The increased entropy can induce the formation of lattice defects, thereby leading to the positive shift binding energies of metal sites. During the OER process, the Ni-O bond was activated and tranformed to NiOOH, which participated in the AEM pathway. Generally, the synthesis of HEMs with abundant defects requires reaction at elevated temperatures, which poses a challenge to the control of morphology and grain size. Gu et al. [65] developed a low-temperature plasma strategy for generating oxygen vacancies in HEOs. The prepared HEMs exhibited rich oxygen vacancies on the surface, which can efficiently promote catalytic activity. He et al. [57] prepared a (Fe0.2Co0.2Ni0.2Cr0.2Mn0.2)3O4 catalyst by a solution combustion method under 110 °C. The as-prepared catalyst exhibits a high density of grain boundary and abundant lattice defects (Fig. 3g). During the OER, The electron transfer from adjacent metal centers to Ni sites facilitated the generation of hydroxyl-containing amorphous intermediate oxides. DFT calculations indicate that oxygen vacancies migrated to Ni sites of the low valence state, which was favorable for dehydrogenation and thus improved catalytic activity (Fig. 3h). To further illustrate the effect of defects on surface adsorption, Zhang et al. [58] constructed a nanoporous high entropy metallic glass (HEMG) of (FeCoNiB0.75)97Pt3 for HER and OER via melt spinning technology. Due to the mismatch of atomic sizes between metallic atoms and the interstitial solid solution of B atoms, the as-prepared sample exhibited pronounced lattice distortion defects. These defects altered the coordination environment for Pt, leading to a shortened Pt-Pt bond. This bond shortening was caused by the oxidation of metal atoms during the electrochemical dealloying process. Consequently, the electron transfer capability was significantly enhanced, facilitating the increased surface interaction of H* and·H2O (Fig. 3i and j), which was conducive to the HER and OER activity. Defect engineering in solid materials has been widely investigated to enhance catalytic performance, particularly for OER catalysts.The formed defects can provide additional active sites that can directly participate in the electrocatalytic reaction process. They can also induce partial electron transfer to metal active sites and the redistribution of surface electrons. Furthermore, defect engineering has been shown to lower the d-band centers, thereby optimizing the adsorption energy of reactants onto active sites. This in turn has been demonstrated to lower reaction energy barrier and enhance catalytic activity. 2.3 Crystal phase engineering Intermetallics, defined by the occupation of each crystallographic site by a specific element, allow precise control of the surface electronic structure. This is due to the explicit nature of their crystal structures and the clear definition of the d-orbital interaction [66]. In contrast to the disordered structure, intermetallics with a long-range ordered structure exhibit stronger interatomic bonding, thereby enhancing corrosion resistance, a property that is particularly advantageous in harsh environments [67]. Furthermore, the tunable stoichiometries and crystal structures can lead to the generation of isolated active sites. As a result, intermetallics show considerable potential for electrocatalytic performance. As a pioneering example, Wang et al. [68] reported the preparation of mesoporous high-entropy intermetallics (HEIs) of M−PtM1 (M1 = Pd and/or Rh) in multi-component double-gyroid structures (Fig. 4 a-c). Theoretical simulations have shown that the ordered intermetallic structure exhibited a closed d-band center towards the Fermi level, modulating surface adsorption for intermediates and lowering reaction energy barrier for ORR. However, the formation of intermetallics generally requires a high-temperature annealing process to overcome kinetic energy barrier for atomic diffusion and ordering, resulting in excessive particle size growth and frequent phase separation. In order to overcome the aforementioned drawbacks, Zhu et al. [69] prepared a L12-ordered intermetallic of CoFeNiCuPd using ligand-assisted interfacial assembly (Fig. 4d-f). Due to the strong electronic interaction between metal atoms, the as-prepared intermetallic exhibited the closed d-band center towards the Fermi level, which favored the electron transfer for surface adsorption. Furthermore, Feng et al. [70] fabricated a single-phase HEI of PtIrFeCoCu by a combined chemical co-reduction and annealing process. The as-prepared HEI exhibited a fine-tuned electronic structure that shifted the d-band center of Pt active sites (Fig. 4g and h). Contrary to the conventional research findings, they highlighted that the low index (001) facet of Pt exhibited higher activity than the high index (111) facet, corresponding to more directly facing atoms (Fig. 4i). Notably, the HEI catalyst exhibited a power density of 1.73 W cm−2 when used in a full cell configuration. The preparation of HEIs based on a low-temperature solution annealing method is typically limited to metals with low melting points and high reduction potentials. This method is less effective for metals with high melting points and low reduction potentials due to their slow atomic diffusion. Hu et al. [71] developed a volume confinement strategy to control the transformation of HEIs from crystalline solid solution by tuning the annealing temperature (Fig. 5 a). The particle size of the prepared hollow carbon sphere-confined HEAs nanoparticles can be controlled within a range of approximately 5.9 nm without particle aggregation, even for HEIs prepared below 1000 °C (Fig. 5b and c). In a similar study, Chen et al. [72] employed MOF-derived porous carbon nitrides combined with high-temperature annealing to spatially confine the growth of PtFeCoNiCuZn nanoparticles into intermetallic structures.The average particle size of the prepared HEI was found to be about 2 nm, and it had a mass activity of 2.403 A mgPt −1 at 0.90 V towards ORR. The strong ligand effect resulted in the electron transfer from non-noble metal atoms to Pt atoms, leading to the formation of a strong M−M bond and increased structural stability (Fig. 5d and e). Moreover, multi-metallic HEMs have been observed to readily form amorphous structures, exhibiting exceptional interfacial compatibility. The generation of unsaturated sites in low coordination states within the amorphous structure of HEMs result in enhanced catalytic activity when compared with their crystalline form [73]. In a related study, Huang et al. [74] reported a disordered PtRhPdIrRu HEA containing the short-range order, amorphous regions, and lattice defects (Fig. 5f-h), which were conducive to enhanced catalytic activity. Zhou et al. [75] found that the amorphization of HEAs can downshift the d-band centers of metal atoms to overlap with the p-band of oxygen during OER. Consequently, the covalency of the M−O bond is enhanced, thereby facilitating the catalytic kinetics. In a separate study, Yu et al. [76] utilized the melt-spinning process with acidic solution treatment to engineer an amorphous-crystalline heterostructured CuAgAuPtPd HEA. Theoretical calculations showed that the amorphous-crystalline structure can strengthen the surface adsorption of H2O molecules on active sites and accelerate the decomposition of·H2O to form *H and *OH. Consequently, the as-prepared catalyst exhibited high OER and HER activities, with an overpotential of 208 and 9.5 mV in an acidic electrolyte, and 200 and 10 mV in an alkaline electrolyte, respectively, at 10 mA cm−2. Even though HEIs exhibit both excellent catalytic activity and stability towards HER, OER and ORR, there are still a number of formidable difficulties and challenges. The preparation of HEIs in a pure phase, without phase separation, still faces significant difficulties and challenges. Significantly, the synthesis and design of HEIs can present significant challenges due to the complexity of their compositions and structures, which arise from their large configurational entropy. As a result, conventional manufacturing methods are either inapplicable or financially unfeasible for large-scale commercial production of HEIs, necessitating the development of innovative synthesis routes and processing techniques. 3 Electrocatalytic mechanisms of HEMs 3.1 Hydrogen evolution reaction Hydrogen is considered a promising candidate to replace traditional non-renewable energy sources, such as fossil fuels, due to its status as a carbon–neutral energy carrier with high energy density and zero pollutant emission. This viewpoint is increasingly recognized in the context of environmental degradation and resource depletion [77,78]. The electrolysis of water, driven by renewable electricity, is widely regarded as an important pathway to produce green hydrogen [79]. Despite the development of numerous HER electrocatalysts, there is still an urgent need for high-performance and low-cost electrocatalysts. The HER process occurring on the surface of electrocatalysts follows a two-step reaction pathway in an acidic solution. The first step is electrochemical hydrogen adsorption (Volmer), and the second step is electrochemical hydrogen desorption (Heyrovsky) or chemical hydrogen desorption (Tafel) [80]. The first step in the HER reaction is the adsorption of an H atom onto the catalyst surface. In an acidic electrolyte, this step requires the transfer of a proton to the catalyst surface, where it subsequently bonds with an electron. It has been found that the efficiency of H2 production in the overall water splitting process is significantly limited by the Volmer step due to its sluggish kinetics. The fabrication of HEMs represents a promising approach for accelerating the Volmer step kinetics in HER due to their tunable compositions and electronic structures. For example, Feng et al. [81] designed an ultra-small high entropy NiCoFePtRh alloy (∼1.68 nm). The slightly shifted Pt L3-edge and Rh K-edge reveal the electron transfer from neighboring Ni, Co and Fe atoms to Pt and Rh atoms. During the HER process, the fcc Rh site exhibited the strongest H* adsorption to the Volmer step, while the top Pt-fcc Pt model exhibited the lowest H* desorption energy barrier (0.238 eV), contributing to the Tafel step (Fig. 6 a and b). The as-prepared electrocatalyst exhibited a mass activity of 28.3 A mg−1 noble metals at −0.05 V (40.4 times higher than that of the commercial Pt/C) for HER in a 0.5 M H2SO4 solution with reliable stability (Fig. 6c). In addition, Fu et al. [82] designed a high entropy PdMoGaInNi nanosheet with a weakened hydrogen binding energy of Pt to bring it closer to the peak of the volcano plot (Fig. 6d). This precisely designed electrocatalyst exhibited an overpotential of 13 mV at 10 mA cm−2. The Sabatier principle provides a framework for the preparation of electrocatalysts to improve catalytic performance. HEMs with multicomponent space possess complex spatial and surface active sites, enabling them with unusual adsorption capacities for intermediates. The adsorption strength of certain electrocatalysts is conducive to reactant activation, while those with weaker adsorption are advantageous for hydrogen production. This complex phenomenon introduces significant challenges in elucidating catalytic mechanisms, yet simultaneously offers new avenues to circumvent the intrinsic limitations of the Volcano plot. Chen et al. [83] defined two new descriptors of μ and σ, which determine the location and the variance of ΔGH*, respectively, to reveal the catalytic activity of HEA catalysts for HER using the Gaussian distribution [X ∼ N(μ, σ 2)]. The μ is positively related to the intensity of the compressive strain, while the σ is insignificantly influenced by the compressive strain (Fig. 6e). Furthermore, the active sites in HEMs for the Volmer step exhibit the smallest ΔGH*, while the active sites for the Tafel or Heyrovsky step exhibit the largest ΔGH* (Fig. 6f). These results reveal that the strain effect is of great importance for the enhancement of the catalytic performance of HEMs electrocatalysts towards HER. As mentioned above, HER follows the pathway consisting of the Volmer step followed by the Heyrovsky or Tafel step in alkaline environments [84]. The premature decomposition of water molecules is essential; however, both processes may introduce an additional energy barrier to the H-OH bond cleavage and consequently affect the overall reaction rate. To accelerate the water dissociation kinetics, Yao et al. [85] developed a nanoporous CuAlNiMoFe HEM electrode with an overpotential of 240 mV to achieve a current density of 1840 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH (2.3 times higher than that of Pt/C/Ni). The incorporation of Ni, Mo, and Fe atoms caused the evident lattice distortion in this nanoporous CuAlNiMoFe HEM material, which can reduce the water dissociation energy barrier at the surface electrode, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity and durability. This allowed the efficient dissociation of H2O molecules into H* and HO*, which ewere subsequently adsorbed on Ni(Fe) and Mo sites, respectively. In the case of electrocatalysts towards HER, only the edge sites are active for electrocatalysts toward HER, while the other sites remain less active. To activate the activity of the basal plane, Wang et al. [86] designed a series of high-entropy metal-phosphorus trichalcogenides for HER (Fig. 7 a). The as-prepared materials exhibited an amorphous atomic arrangement and an expanded lattice (Fig. 7b and c), resulting in partial electrons transferring from S atoms to P atoms (Fig. 7d), thereby facilitating the formation of P-H*. Consequently, the P sites on the basal plane were activated and acted as active sites for hydrogen adsorption. In addition, the P sites and metal sites on the edge can act as active sites for efficient water dissociation. The optimized Co0.6(VMnNiZn)0.4PS3 nanosheets present an overpotential of 65.9 mV at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 7e) and a Tafel slope of 65.5 mV dec−1. Furthermore, Mao et al. [87] demonstrated that the random distribution of multiple elements within the HEM phase can enhance the HER activity of electrocatalysts. This is due to the ability of such elements to form lattice distortions and defects (Fig. 7f), thereby enabling a strong coupling effect and facilitating electron transfer between different active sites (Fig. 7g). These studies have shown that the amorphous structure of HEMs with random atomic arrangement and lattice distortion can facilitate surface electron transfer, thereby enhancing the catalytic performance of HERs. Although HEMs demonstrate high catalytic activity and stability, the presence of multicomponent active sites complicates the understanding of the catalytic mechanisms involved in HER. To enhance the d-d electron interaction of PtMoPdRhNi HEA nanocrystals, Wei et al. [88] incorporated half-full Mo (4d5) and full (4d10) Pd valence electrons to enhance the d-d electron interaction of PtMoPdRhNi HEA nanocrystals. The in-situ surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy revealed that Pt and Ni sites were the active sites for water dissociation, while the Pt and Rh sites are the direct active sites for H* adsorption/desorption (Fig. 7h). These results demonstrate that the HEMs are among the most promising electrocatalysts with great potential for HER application with high activity [89]. In addition, the HER performance of the latest HEM electrocatalysts in relation to their structural features is summarized in Table S1 [51,52,58,74,81–83,86–106]. High entropy catalysts, in particular low Pt-based HEAs, show both high electrocatalytic activity and stability under high current density conditions for HER catalysis. Multiple metal elements of HEMs provide a wealth of interaction sites, thereby increasing the catalytic efficiency, minimizing catalyst degradation over long periods. While HEMs have shown impressive performance in alkaline media, their activity is still generally lower than that of catalysts operated in acidic conditions. This discrepancy poses a significant challenge to the widespread application of HEA catalysts in alkaline exchange membrane fuel cells and water electrolysis cells. 3.2 Oxygen evolution reaction OER, which occurs at the anode of the water electrolyzer, also plays a critical role in hydrogen production. In an alkaline environment, OER follows the OHads → Oads → OOHads → O2ads process (AEM, adsorbate evolution mechanism), where the sluggish catalytic kinetics of OER associated with the large energy barrier (4.92 eV) tend to cause a low efficiency of hydrogen production efficiency [111,112]. The development of HEMs with functional structural features provides an opportunity to prepare high-performance OER electrocatalysts (Table S2) [56,57,108,110,113–135]. Typically, Kante et al. [136] developed a HEO thin film of LaCr0.2Mn0.2Fe0.2Co0.2Ni0.2O3− δ with a well-ordered crystal structure, and the OER occurred on the (001) facet of the prepared electrocatalyst, which exhibited an enhanced catalytic activity compared to other single-site parent compounds in 0.1 M KOH. This well-defined catalyst has a high density of states near the Fermi level, which has previously been shown to be sufficient for highly active perovskite OER catalysts. The OER performance of HEMs is dependent on their architectural parameters. He et al. [107] used a 4d Mo- and 5d W-coordinated FeCoNi alloy to construct FeCoNiMoW HEA with internal strains along the (111) and (−200) zone axis for OER. As the internal distortions and strains led to the closed d-band centers, the FeCoNiMoW HEA exhibited an enhanced anti-bonding orbital with a reduced occupation degree, thereby enhancing the surface adsorption for the OOH* intermediate (Fig. 8 a). This property results in the reduced reaction energy barrier and enhanced OER activity. These results highlight the significant application potential of HEMs in OER for hydrogen production. The OER process can be divided into four successive proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) steps, the mechanistic investigation of which is hindered by multi-element compositions and intricate structural configurations of the system. In their study, Beak et al. [108] investigated the OER activity of high entropy spinel oxides (HESO) resulting from the local mixing near the active sites. The local tensile (compressive) strain of the M−O bonds strengthened (weakened) the binding of O* and OH*. The Fe atom coordinated to the surface neighbor can bring the tensile strain to attract O, while the Mn and Cr sites that were neighboring the surface and sub-surface can induce compressive strain, weakening the O* and OH* adsorption (Fig. 8b). The CoFeNiCrMn HEO with an optimized structure exhibited an overpotential of 307 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and a 12% increase in overpotential over 168 h. Triolo et al. [109] investigated the effect of metal atom occupation on 16d sites for OER activity regulation. Cations with a reduced 3d electron count occupying the 16d sites exhibit optimal e g orbital filling (Fig. 8c). This electronic configuration promotes favorable surface adsorption, thereby accelerating catalytic kinetics and improving overall activity (Fig. 8d).During the OER process, the unavoidable dissolution and oxidation of metal atoms on the surface of electrocatalysts leads to the formation of reconstructed products. These products have a significant effect on the catalytic performance and are generally considered to be the true active sites. Typically, Huang et al. [104] reported that the development of the defects and lattice strain in FeCoNiRu alloy can induce surface reconstruction to facilitate HER for high hydrogen production. In order to explore the surface reconstruction process of HEMs, Han et al. [110] constructed an amorphous NiFeCoMnAl oxide catalyst for OER. The formed β-NiOOH on Mn-coordinated Ni sites can act as real active sites to improve the catalytic performance with an overpotential of 190 mV (smaller than 245 mV for RuO2) at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 8e and f). In a separate study, Luan et al. [137] investigated the structure–activity-stability relationships of FeCoNiCrMn HEA. In the KOH electrolyte, Cr, Mn, and Co atoms underwent dissolution and subsequent depletion on the surface (Fig. 9 a). During the subsequent cycling process, the NiFe-rich oxyhydroxide was formed, thereby enhancing the OER activity (Fig. 9b). Conversely, as OER proceeded, the Ni/Fe ratio of the NiFe-oxyhydroxide formed was reduced due to the Fe dissolution and redeposition, leading to a decrease in OER activity. However, the Cr-rich oxide and oxygen-rich layer were formed below the NiFe-rich oxyhydroxide, preventing the outward diffusion and continuous dissolution of Ni, Co, Mn, and Fe from the bulk (Fig. 9c). Compared to the prevailing AEM mechanism, the Lattice Oxygen-participated Mechanism (LOM) has been postulated as a potential avenue to enhance the catalytic activity of OER. The LOM mechanism is a theoretical framework that delineates the reaction pathways of OH–, O2 2–, and O2 during water oxidation. This mechanism involves the activation and redox reactions of lattice oxygen, thereby facilitating the direct coupling of O-O bonds [140,141]. The LOM mechanism has the potential to circumvent the constraints in the linear AEM relationships, which may ultimately result in a reduction in the reaction energy potential during OER. Metal ion dopants have been employed to decrease the energy of the d orbital of the central metal, facilitating the overlap between the d orbital of the metal and the p orbital energy level of the oxygen in the catalyst [142,143]. As demonstrated by Tang et al. [138], the formation of oxygen vacancies in the plane sites (x2-y2) of the CoO6 octahedron (1st layer) in the ABO3 type HEO surface can facilitate the generation of OO*-(Vo) and promote the LOM mechanism (Fig. 10 a and b). The as-prepared La0.6Sr0.4Co0.2Fe0.2Mn0.2Ni0.2Mg0.2O3 electrocatalyst exhibited an overpotential of 320 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and a low Tafel slope of 45 mV dec−1. To further investigate the origin of the LOM pathway, Wang et al. [139] used Au atoms to activate the lattice oxygen of the HELDH of MnFeCoNiCu (Fig. 10c). The O 2p band center closer to the E F played a crucial role in releasing the lattice oxygen to the weak M−O bond and triggering the LOM pathway. The synergistic interaction between the incorporated Au single atoms and O vacancies led to an upshift of the O 2p band, weakening the metal-O bond, triggering the LOM, lowering the energy barrier and increasing the intrinsic activity (Fig. 10d and e). According to the LOM mechanism, the as-prepared HELDH exhibited OER activity with an overpotential of 213 mV at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 10f) and a mass activity of 732.925 A g−1 at 250 mV, in addition to 700 h of uninterrupted operation at ∼100 mA cm−2 in 1.0 M KOH. The critical limitation for LOM is mainly attributed to the strong orbital hybridization of the M−O bond due to the high oxidation state of the metals. Therefore, a key strategy for activating the LOM mechanism involves inducing substantial charge polarization between metal cations and oxygen anions, thereby facilitating intramolecular electron transfer through enhanced metal–oxygen covalency. Zhang et al. [115] designed a nanoporous NiFeCoMnOOH (np-NiFeCoMnOOH) electrocatalyst based on the discovery that the NiFeCoMnOOH in equal elemental ratios (ere-NiFeCoMnOOH) followed the LOM pathway towards OER. During the OER, an ultra-thin NiFeCoMnOOH layer was reconstructed on the np-NiFeCoMn surface (Fig. 10g). Ni and Fe sites on the reconstructed NiFeCoMnOOH surface were found to be active sites as evidenced by LOM, and the closed O 2p orbitals towards E F were found to promote the catalytic kinetics. Consequently, this HEO electrocatalyst exhibited an overpotential of 194 mV, with a 5 mV increase over a 120 h period at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 10 h). The use of an acidic OER is preferable to an alkaline one, as the former can provide a wider load range and significantly improve the operational safety of an acidic electrolyzer by largely preventing the formation of the H2/O2 mixture [144]. Nevertheless, due to the high cleavage energy of the O–H covalent bond and the severe metal corrosion, the fabrication of high-performance acidic OER electrocatalysts is challenging. In this context, HEMs, which have the characteristics of multi-sites and high corrosion resistance, are particularly suitable for acidic OER. Typically, Kwon et al. [145] designed a ZnNiCoIrMn HEA for OER, which presented an overpotential of 237 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 0.1 M HClO4. The mass activity of ZnNiCoIrMn at 1.5 VRHE was 610.8 A gIr −1, which exceeded the commercial Ir/C electrocatalyst (122.8 A gIr −1). To further improve the activity and stability, Hu et al. [133] designed a homogeneous electrocatalyst of grain boundary (GB)-rich M−RuIrFeCoNiO2 (Fig. 11 a). The synergistic effects of transition metal doping and GB formation promoted charge accumulation on RuO2 active sites, thereby weakening OH– adsorption strength through electronic structure modulation (Fig. 11b–e), resulting in an improvement of the catalytic activity. The efficient inhibition of lattice oxygen participation in OER can be achieved by Ir doping, thus stabilizing RuO2. The prepared HEO electrocatalyst exhibited an overpotential of 189 mV at 10 mV s−1 and solid stability over 120 h in 0.5 M H2SO4. Similarly, Yao et al. [131] designed a core–shell structure consisting of IrRuCoNiMo core-IrRuNiMoO x shell through a surface transition metal galvanic replacement strategy (Fig. 11f). The projected density of states (PDOS) plots revealed that with the low d-band center of Ir towards E F, the Ir active sites in HEO can lower the surface adsorption energy of O-containing intermediates, thereby decreasing free energy barrier and enhancing OER activity (Fig. 11g). The anodic current induced the transformation of Ir and Ru into Ru/Ir oxides, establishing them as the active sites for OER. The formation of IrRuNiMoO x shells significantly reduced metal dissolution, thus ensuring the robustness and stability of the electrocatalysts. As expected, the as-prepared electrocatalysts demonstrated the OER performance with an overpotential of 243 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and underwent a 24 h chronopotentiometry test at 50 mA cm−2 in 0.5 M H2SO4 (Fig. 11 h). Maulana et al. [127] designed an IrFeCoNiCu-HEA for the acidic OER. The as-prepared electrocatalyst delivered an overpotential of 302 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and demonstrated no loss of activity over a period of 12 h in 0.1 M HClO4. The dissolution of metals into the solution resulted in the deposition of metal atoms onto the surface of HEA, leading to the formation of an IrOx film or a multimetallic oxide film. These films were found to be unevenly distributed. The most active sites in enhancing OER activity were identified as the high valence Ir and IrO x . Ru- and Ir-based HEMs exhibit excellent catalytic activity and robust stability towards OER in acidic environments. Consequently, they can be potentially applied to overall water splitting for efficient hydrogen production. However, due to the limited and high cost of such HEMs, there is an urgent need to develop non-noble metal HEMs. Chang et al. [92] prepared a FeCoNiMnW HEA that can be operated in 0.5 M H2SO4 towards OER, achieving an overpotential of 512 mV at 10 mA cm−2 with a lifespan of 6 days. The reconstruction of metal oxides on the surface of HEAs played a crucial role in enhancing the OER activity, while the W 4f helped to stabilize the electrocatalyst. Due to their abundance of terminated atoms and amorphous structure, HEMGs have significant potential as a catalyst for the acidic OER due to their unique geometric properties. Jo et al. [146] introduced p-orbital elements into HEMG systems and constructed a CoFeNiMoWTe HEMG system for the acidic OER. The incorporation of Te enabled the generation of amorphous structure and atomic defects, which provided abundant terminal atoms and induced the increased valence states of metal cations. This HEMG electrocatalyst exhibited an overpotential of 373 mV and underwent a 100 h durability test at 10 mA cm−2 in 0.5 M H2SO4. The development of acidic OER electrocatalysts has lagged behind that of alkaline OER electrocatalysts. Therefore, the development of robust, high-performance electrocatalysts with exceptional activity under prolonged acidic operation represents a critical research priority, particularly for advancing durable acidic AEM electrolyzers. To boost the OER activity, various surface engineering techniques have been developed for HEMs, although their performance still falls short of industrial applications. HEMs are considered as promising candidates for OER due to their tailored surface electronic structure, which can regulate surface adsorption for O-containing intermediates and promote O-O bond cleavage to facilitate OER activity. The O–O bond cleavage determines the catalytic activity of OER catalysts. HEMs catalysts can induce direct O–O bond cleavage in *O2 via the LOM pathway, which has been considered as an efficient strategy to enhance OER performance. However, the triggering of the LOM mechanism is highly dependent on the activation of the lattice oxygen. During the LOM process, the structural evolution of the lattice oxygen leads to a dynamic transformation of the material structure. Furthermore, the AEM and LOM mechanisms do not occur independently but can occur simultaneously on the surface of catalysts. The advanced structural properties of HEMs facilitate the occurrence of the LOM mechanism but also pose significant challenges for the study of their catalytic mechanisms. To explore the HEM-based LOM mechanism and the surface reconstruction phenomenon, it is essential to combining the advanced characterization techniques with in-depth theoretical calculations. 3.3 Oxygen reduction reaction The ORR is defined as the complete four-electron (4e−) transfer process that occurs at the cathode of PEMFCs [147]. In a series of ORR pathways for Pt-based catalysts, the first electron transfer from the topmost electrode surface to the adsorbed molecular oxygen (O2ads) is considered to be the rate-determining step [148]. In an acidic environment, each O2 molecule is electrocatalytically reduced and combines with four protons to form two H2O molecules, as shown in the reaction below [149]. O2 + 4H+ + 4e- → 2H2O In an alkaline medium, water acts as a proton donor, while hydroxide and electrolyte ions exert an influence on the adsorption energies of hydrogen and water molecules, modulating the kinetics of the underlying reactions [150]. O2 + 2H2O + 4e- → 4OH- High entropy catalysts are considered to be one of the most promising candidates for reducing cost and providing high ORR activity due to their multi-site characteristics. Wang et al. [151] designed a porous carbon-supported PtFeNiCoMn HEA catalyst to boost ORR activity in 0.1 M HClO4 solution. This as-prepared HEA nanoparticle exhibited a small size of about 2.4 nm with a compressive strain of 6 % (Fig. 12 a). The DFT calculations showed that the electron transfer from non-precious metals to Pt can downshift the d-band center of Pt, weakening the binding strength of reactions on Pt sites and thereby facilitating the surface desorption of intermediates. Notably, this catalyst delivered a mass capacity of 1.12 A mgpt −1, which was remarkably higher than that of commercial Pt/C catalysts (0.30 A mgpt −1). In another work, Zhang et al. [152] drove the electric dipole transition to enhance the ORR activity of HESO in 1 M KOH electrolyte (Fig. 12b and c). The designed FeCoNiCrMn HESO with high lattice distortion exhibited electron transitions from 3d/4s orbitals to 4p orbitals and the formation of new p-like hybridized orbitals. The strong electric dipole transitions induced the redistribution of the surface electronic structure (Fig. 12d), brought the unpaired Co t2g occupancy and thereby activated the octahedral Co sites. This well-designed catalyst exhibited a half-wave potential of 0.87 V and a small Tafel slope of 62 mV dec−1 towards ORR. HEAs catalysts have advantages with respect to ORR; however, the infinite element compositions make the development of highly active HEAs challenging using traditional preparation methods. Pan et al. [153] proposed a procedural high-throughput experimental method for Pt-based HEAs in 0.1 M HClO4 solution. The elemental composition played a pivotal role in the performance of the active sites for Pt-M HEAs (M = Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, Cu, Mo, Sn, and Ce). Among all the samples, the FeNiCuCoPt exhibited the lowest reaction energy barrier due to the synergistic effect between Cu and Co (Fig. 12 e-g), which moved the closed d-band center towards the Fermi level, thereby enhancing the binding strength of *O on Fe active sites. The FeNiCuCoPt HEA delivered the optimal ORR activity with a half-wave potential of 0.892 V and a mass activity of 1.32 A mgpt −1, respectively. The utilization of HEIs in long-range ordered structures has been identified as a promising avenue to achieve high activity. Zhang et al. [154] designed an L12-type PtM3 (M = FeCoNiCuZn) intermetallic for acidic ORR application. The as-prepared PtM3 HEI catalyst exhibited the downshifted binding energy of Pt 4f, attributed to electron transfer from M to Pt. This modulated the surface electronic structure, thereby weakening the binding energy of reactions at active sites. Furthermore, the negative free energy of HEI was shown to limit metal dissolution and secondary Ostwald ripening/agglomeration degradation, thereby enhancing the stability of the catalyst. This catalyst presented a mass activity of 0.7 A mgPt −1 in an acidic solution and retained 97.1% of its initial mass activity after 30,000 potential cycles. N dopant enhances structural stability through atomic pinning effects, where coordinatively bound N atoms effectively anchor adjacent metal centers, thereby suppressing metal dissolution and lattice destabilization. The catalytic activity is closely related to the coordination environment and the non-bonding interaction between the center atoms and other components. In a related study, Tamtaji et al. [155] utilized machine learning to predict the ORR activity of high entropy single-atom catalysts (M = Fe, Co, Ni and Ru) with different intermetallic distances, thereby investigating the non-bonding interaction for ORR activity in acidic and alkaline environments. The calculated counterplot shows that the Fe sites have the highest ORR activity with a limiting potential of 0.79 V and an overpotential of 0.44 V for the intermetallic distance of 6.11 Å (Fig. 13 a). For the ORR, the OH* protonation was considered as the potential determining step, where the Fe z-axis d orbitals hybridize with the p x orbital of OH* (Fig. 13b). Stability is a key parameter in assessing the potential application of a catalyst in industrial contexts. However, the occurrence of severe metal leaching in acidic environments can lead to irreversible structural degradation, which is detrimental to the maintenance of activity and ultimately decreases the stability. To maintain a stable output of high ORR activity, Zhang et al. [156] used ordered mesoporous carbon to anchor PtNiFeCuCoZn HEA to stabilize ORR activity in 0.1 M HClO4 solution. The strong interaction between the HEA and porous carbon could confine the PtNiFeCuCoZn HEA to a size of 2.2 nm, thereby ensuring stable ORR activity over 5000 cycles with only a 2% decrease in activity in acidic environments. Despite the remarkable catalytic activity and durability of HEI catalysts for ORR, the complex crystal nucleation process poses significant challenges to the investigation of the underlying mechanisms. In the study conducted by Wang et al. [101], the metal dissolution behavior during the ORR process was investigated to elucidate the catalytic mechanism and stability. To this end, Pt4FeCoCuNi HEAs with different degrees of ordering were prepared (Fig. 13c and d). The intrinsic ORR activity was correlated with the degree of structural order. The high entropy strategy can effectively downshift the d-band center of Pt, thereby moderating the excessive adsorption for reactions on the Pt catalyst surface, although the d-band center of a highly ordered structure is higher than that of a partially ordered or disordered structure. For example, a highly ordered Pt4FeCoCuNi HEA exhibited optimized ORR activity with a mass activity of 3.78 A mgpt −1. During the ORR process, a Pt shell consisting of 3 ∼ 4 atomic layers was formed on its surface due to the leaching and dissolution of non-noble metals (Fig. 13e), resulting in a 74% activity retention (2.77 A mgpt −1) after 30 K cycles. Additionally, Zhao et al. [48] doped N atoms into PtFeCoNiCu HEA with a Pt-rich skin to rationalize the positive function on ORR activity and stability. The as-prepared catalyst exhibited 79.1 % mass activity (1.34 A mgPt −1) after 30 K cycles. The characterizations showed that the N-doping process resulted in the formation of metal-N bonds, thus providing robust chemical bonds within the HEA (Fig. 13f). The DFT calculation results showed that when the N atoms in the octahedral center coordinated with Fe, Co and Ni at the lowest energy, the surface electronic structure was modulated to optimize the −ΔG (U0) and −ΔG (U0) (Fig. 13g and h), facilitating the conversion of *O from O2 and H2O from *OH. In summary, HEMs offer significant advantages for ORR due to their improved durability, enriched active sites, tunable electronic structures, and high catalytic activity and stability. In HEMs, different metal elements contribute to a synergistic effect where each element modifies the electronic structure of the others. This leads to enhanced charge transfer and orbital overlap, promoting strong bonding and structural stability. In ORR, this synergistic effect can activate not only the noble metal sites but also the non-noble metal sites, forming multiple active centers that significantly improve catalytic performance. These unique properties make high-entropy catalysts promising candidates for improving the performance of fuel cells and other electrochemical devices that rely on efficient ORR. 4 Summary and Outlook HEMs have significant potential for HER, OER and ORR, and can be used in zero-emission power source systems combining AEMs and PEMFCs. The high entropy has been shown to reduce the Gibbs energy of materials, leading to the development of unique geometric and surface electronic properties. It has also been demonstrated to shift the d-band center of active sites, thereby modulating surface adsorption and enhancing catalytic activity. This review provides an overview of the most recent discoveries in HEMs catalysts for HER, OER and ORR applications. To achieve high-performance electrocatalysis and ensure solid stability, precise structural design strategies are proposed to regulate the surface electronic structure of catalysts. The catalytic mechanism is related to the structural properties of HEMs, and the performance of catalysts towards HER, OER, and ORR is generalized. Although significant progress has been made in the field of electrocatalysis, HEMs still face numerous challenges and problems that need to be addressed. Firstly, the synthesis of large-scale production of HEMs requires precise control over morphological uniformity and phase homogeneity while meeting industrial-scale production demands, which is a challenging task. This complexity arises from the inherent need to overcome the significant hurdles posed by high configuration entropy and formation enthalpy during the HEM fabrication process. These factors require sophisticated strategies to ensure the formation of a stable solid solution phase while mitigating phase separation and grain growth, which can adversely affect catalytic performance. Despite notable advances in synthetic methodologies to address these challenges, such as carbothermal shock synthesis, wet chemical approaches, melt spinning techniques and arc melting technologies, these strategies are often limited to the laboratory scale. Scaling up HEM production while maintaining their structural integrity and catalytic performance remains a critical challenge for industrial adoptionThe limitations of these methods are often due to their complexity, cost and scalability issues, making it difficult to achieve the economies of scale required for commercial viability. Consequently, developing scalable, cost-effective synthetic methodologies to bridge the lab-to-industry gap represents a critical research priority.Such methods must not only ensure the formation of high-quality HEMs with the desired morphologies and compositions but also be adaptable to large-scale production while maintaining cost-effectiveness. Overcoming this challenge is essential for the future commercialization of HEM catalysts, paving the way for their widespread adoption in various industrial sectors, including energy conversion, environmental remediation and chemical synthesis. Secondly, the local coordination environment of active sites in HEMs, particularly the spatial configuration of nearest-neighbor atoms, critically governs their catalytic performance. The uniform distribution of elements with optimal spatial configurations facilitates the provision of active sites with favorable electronic properties, which are crucial for improving catalytic efficiency. Therefore, precise control of the elemental distribution within HEMs is of paramount importance to achieve optimal catalytic performance. The incorporation of a large number of transition metals into HEMs introduces a wide range of possible elemental configurations, posing significant challenges in terms of experimental synthesis and design optimization. The complex interactions between different elements within HEMs can profoundly influence the binding strength of adsorbates to active sites, thereby potentially enhancing catalytic performance. However, the optimization of component composition for the specific catalytic application remains a formidable task. The multitude of possible elemental combinations in varying ratios complicates the process of determining the optimal composition for a given reaction. In this context, machine learning (ML) has emerged as a promising approach for predicting and improving the catalytic properties of HEMs. Using advanced algorithms and large datasets, ML can facilitate the rapid identification of optimal elemental compositions and spatial configurations, thereby accelerating the discovery of novel HEMs compositions with superior performance. This approach has the potential to revolutionize the design and optimization of HEMs catalysts, enabling more efficient and selective catalytic processes in a wide range of industrial applications. Thirdly, it is necessary to undertake a detailed analysis of their unique properties and methodologies to unravel their catalytic mechanisms. A major challenge is the intrinsic complexity of HEMs, which are composed of multiple elements in almost equal proportions. This inherent complexity gives rise to a multitude of interactions and possible configurations at the atomic level, which significantly affect their electronic structure, surface chemistry, and overall catalytic performance. Understanding these intricate interactions and their impact on catalysis requires a high level of sophistication in experimental and computational techniques. An important aspect of this challenge is the identification and characterization of active sites within HEMs. Due to their high entropy nature, active sites may not be readily identifiable or may exist in a dynamic equilibrium, making it difficult to pinpoint their exact location and structure. This underscores the necessity for the development of sophisticated characterization techniques capable of probing the catalyst at the atomic scale with both high spatial and temporal resolution. Consequently, high-resolution scanning tunneling microscopy (STM), X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) and electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) have emerged as valuable techniques for probing the local structure and electronic properties of HEMs. Finally, another major challenge pertains to the dynamic nature of electrocatalytic reactions, which are characterized by rapid changes in the catalyst surface and the formation of reaction intermediates. The capture of these transient states, and the subsequent comprehension of their roles in the catalytic cycle, is of paramount importance in the development of an accurate depiction of the catalytic mechanism. In-situ experimental techniques, including in-situ electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), in-situ Raman spectroscopy, and ambient pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (AP-XPS), facilitate the real-time observation of these reactions. These techniques provide insights into the dynamic behavior of the catalyst surface and the reaction intermediates, providing essential information for the refinement of catalytic models. However, experimental techniques alone are often insufficient to fully understand the complex mechanisms in HEMs. Theory is therefore required to provide a more complete understanding. Density functional theory and molecular dynamics simulations are powerful tools for modelling the electronic structure, reaction energetics, and dynamic behavior of HEMs. Based on these theoretical calculations that involve the simulation of different configurations and reaction pathways, it is possible to predict catalytic activity, selectivity, and stability. This, in turn, provides a framework for the experimental design and optimization of catalysts. Furthermore, the interplay between experiment and theory is essential to achieve a comprehensive understanding of HEMs in electrocatalysis. Experimental data provide the fundamental truth to validate theoretical models, while theoretical calculations offer insights that can guide experimental design and interpretation. This symbiotic relationship promotes a deeper understanding of the catalytic mechanisms and enables the rational design of high-performance electrocatalysts. In conclusion, the exploration of high entropy catalyst materials in electrocatalysis poses significant challenges due to their inherent complexity and the dynamic nature of electrocatalytic reactions. To address these challenges, a multidisciplinary approach integrating advanced characterization techniques, in-situ characterization methods, and theoretical calculations is imperative. By leveraging the strengths of these methodologies, researchers can gain a more profound understanding of the catalytic mechanisms of HEMs and facilitate the development of high-performance electrocatalysts for various applications. Zibo Zhai received his Ph.D. degree in college of sciences from Shanghai University in 2023, and joined in Dongguan University of Technology in 2023. His research interests include the synthesis of functional materials and their application in electrocatalysis. He has published more than 10 papers in peer-reviewed journals as the first author and corresponding author. Yan-Jie Wang received his Ph.D. in Materials Science & Engineering from the Zhejiang University in 2005. His research interests mainly focus on nanostructured materials in energy storage and conversion, biomass engineering, and medical areas. He is listed as one of the top 2% of scientists in the world (ranked by Stanford University). Baizeng Fang received his Ph.D. in Materials Science from the University of Science and Technology Beijing in 1997. His research interests mainly focus on nanostructured materials for electrochemical energy storage and conversion. He has published more than 220 peer-reviewed SCI papers. He is listed as a Highly Cited Researcher (Clarivate 2023, 2024), one of the Top 0.05% Highly Ranked Scholars (ScholarGPS 2024) and a Fellow of the Royal Society of Chemistry.

coredata.dc:description: High entropy materials (HEMs) are the promising electrocatalysts for anion exchange membrane electrolyser (AEMs) and proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) due to the intriguing cocktail effect, wide design space, tailorable electronic structure, and entropy stabilization effect. The precise fabrication of HEMs with functional nanostructures provides a crucial avenue to optimize the adsorption strength and catalytic activity for electrocatalysis. This review comprehensively summarizes the development of HEMs, focusing on the principles and strategies of structural design, and the catalytic mechanism towards hydrogen evolution reaction, oxygen evolution reaction and oxygen reduction reaction for the development of high-performance electrocatalysts. The complexity inherent in the interactions between different elements, the changes in the d-band center and the Gibbs free energies during the catalytic progress, as well as the coordination environment of the active sites associated with the unique crystal structure to improve the catalytic performance are discussed. We also provide a perspective on the challenges and future development direction of HEMs in electrocatalysis. This review will contribute to the design and development of HEMs-based catalysts for the next generation of electrochemical applications.
